ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: You will gain a better sense of Japanese politics (especially as it relates to elections and parties in Japan).
This was my first course focused on Asialearned so much about the cultural, social, political, and economic systems in Japan
An overview of Japanese history, economics, and politics (both domestic and international).
A good understanding of political science and the political environment of modern Japan.
history of Japan following WW2, clientelist politics, Japanese economy and foreign policy
Focus in detail on Japanese politics
A basic understanding of Japanese political organizations and the way that Japan has globalized its society.
I learned about Japanese political parties, women in Japan, Japan's relation to the west. I don't know if I gained any new skills, but the information was definitely interesting.
Developed more knowledge about Japans history and how it relates geopolitically to the rest of the world
I learned about Japanese politics and Japanese interactions within East Asia and the rest of the world.
I had a better understanding of the workings of Japanese politics and the factors shaping them.

I gained greatly of Japan's premodern to modern history, its international relations, and domestic politics. I believe this could help me greatly in terms of developing my future thesis on writing about Japanese soft power influence in Asia.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
I would like to preface this by saying this semester's class was unusual due to Frances's passing. The depth of her passion for her students was clear until her final days. She was a true expert in her field, and we all learned so much from her. I know how difficult it was to teach a class given the circumstances, and none of the following should be taken as representative of future versions of the course or of the ability of the instructors themselves.

That being said, there were many more fundamental issues with the course. Primarily, it felt as though our instructors did not prepare much for class, which was reflected in the chaotic, confusing, and ungrounded nature of the conversations. This was also an externality of the size of the class, which should have never been as large as it was. To the final week, there were students that had to stand/sit in the back or side of the classroom because there weren't enough seats at the already packed table. With a class this big (or any class for that matter) it is not enough to start a conversation by asking "What did you think about the readings". Finally, the readings on the syllabus did not seem carefully chosen, and were often not brought up at all during class. 

In future iterations of the course, I recommend that: 1) the size be limited to ~15 (instead of >30) students, 2) discussion questions be prepared (or better yet, distributed) before class, and 3) readings be better chosen (and limited) for the topics under discussion. 

There were also clear strengths of the course. Our TA, Colin Moreshead, was fantastic and delivered clear and regular feedback on writing. The structure of the reading responses lended itself well to digesting the material before class. Finally, the topics, when they carefully addressed, were certainly fascinating.
Nice breadth of topics, but could give more opportunities (aside from final paper) for students to engage in depth on that which interests them.

The readings were carefully selected and interesting, and we had good materials to look at in class. Students were just not always that engaged so working to make sure everyone is participating in discussion.

strengths: Colin is awesome, pretty easy, interesting and relevant subject matter
weaknesses: not super well organized, class discussion advantaged students who are well versed in Japan and Asia more broadly
Seminar was slightly disorganized in terms of participation. I wish there would have been a lecture component to the course in order to better conceptualize the material

Due to Professor Rosenbluth's passing, this course operated very differently than expected. I believe that the organization of the class was below average and was due to the fact that it was run by three different people. The discussions were often stagnant and the class didn't have much direction. Again, in the midst of tragedy, it is difficult to criticize the course.

Strengths: Weekly response papers for completion.
Weakness: Your entire grade was based on the final paper so it was a bit hard to tell how you were doing in the class.
Seemed like we did not discuss readings most of the time, felt lost in some discussions that involved outside knowledge
The course was discussion heavy with a lot of questions being thrown to the class. I would have appreciated more moments of traditional lecturing to give a foundation.

The course was very quantitatively focused, which was unexpected. I am new to political sciences, so I dont know if this is just what the field is like, but I would have liked to engage more with qualitative materials.

Strengths: up-to-date contemporary Japanese politics that would affect current international relations; comprehensive readings on the reasons for the formation of contemporary Japanese politics; concrete quantitative data that would reflect the fact without or with only limited biases. 
Weakness: would be better if the teachers lecture more about the reading materials and give less time for student discussions (just my personal opinion) since I believe many students were new to the topic and it would be better for teachers to offer more information in class. (But I overall enjoyed this class!)

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Other evaluations that state this course is great for people with no background in Japanese studies/East Asian studies/political science are likely saying that because it is an easy course to do well in. That doesn't mean you'll actually gain a lot if you don't already have some background in these fields. I expect that this course will change tremendously in following years, so my recommendation is to simply go and see for yourself.
YES  especially if you only have a US-view of politics
Helpful as a broad survey for those lacking pre-existing knowledge about Japan, but may offer less for more advanced students.
If you want a relatively easy and interesting course on Japan that will give you some incite into political science, yes. I took it for a social science credit and it was a great experience.
Yes
yes, interesting and easy
I would, if the class became more organized
Yes! The entire teaching time was really great and helpful through a very difficult time.

Under the circumstances that it is run by one professor with a clear goal in mind, I would recommend it. To be clear, Gento Kato and Colin Moreshead were extremely helpful and supportive of students. I commend them for their efforts.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student if you like Japanese history and politics. It was a pretty standard PLSC seminar.
Yes if you are interested in Japan
Sure, if you are interested in Japan or just want to learn about a new subject it's a good course to take.
Yes, because this is an interesting topic.

Yes. I believe it's a great course to learn about Japan's international politics, especially during the uncertain time when US and China is in competition--Japan plays a significant role in keeping the balance.
